title: Cabrillo National Monument: Permits & Reservations
body: Explore This Park    Plan Your Visit     Basic Information     Permits & Reservations              Permits & Reservations      RESERVATIONSYou're welcome to visit Cabrillo National Monument any time that we're open - no reservations are required for the general public.     SPECIAL USE PERMITS Special Use Permits Update Due to the volume of current special use permits in process, Cabrillo National Monument is currently requiring a 6-8 week processing time for any permit application. We apologize for any inconvenience this may be to you. Permits for National Amateur Radio Operators Due to the high volume of inquiries from amateur radio operators interested in broadcasting from Cabrillo National Monument we are in the process of working with individuals and radio clubs to coordinate activity in the park. Please read the requirements below.    Commonly Requested Permits    Weddings     Tidepool Permits   Request Form (groups larger than 10 people) To request a form, please contact the Education Department at (619) 557-5450 x4589 Tidepool Permit Availability   Commercial filming and photography     Reenlistments     Scattering of ashes     General Guidelines for Special Use Permits Certain types of activities require a special use permit.  These include types of organized gatherings, distribution of printed material, other public expressions of opinion, and other activities that are controlled or prohibited.  See the following definitions and examples to determine if your usage might be included.  A special park use is defined as a short-term activity that takes place in a park area, and that:     Provides a benefit to an individual, group, or organization rather than the public at large; Requires written authorization and some degree of management control from the National Park Service (NPS) in order to protect park resources and the public interest; Is not prohibited by law or regulation; Is not initiated, sponsored, or conducted by the NPS; And is not managed under a concession contract, a recreation activity for which the NPS charges a fee, or a lease.   Examples include: Weddings, ceremonies or public assemblies, events sponsored by an organization for which we act as the venue, etc.  Examples of first amendment activities include: a church service, political event, or freedom of speech act.  For more information regarding Special Use Permits or to determine if your activity requires one, please email us.  Applications should be submitted well in advance, preferably 2-3 months before the event to allow for consideration and processing.     General Special Use Permit Application              Amateur Radio Operators Setup Location        Information regarding the National Association for Amateur Radio and the National Parks on the Air Due to the high volume of inquiries from amateur radio operators interested in broadcasting from Cabrillo National Monument we are in the process of working with individuals and radio clubs to coordinate activity in the park.   At this time, requests to operate within the park that do not fall under the guidelines set forth below will be assessed on a case by case situation and radio operators or clubs may be asked to apply for a special park use permit. For organized group events, contact us for permit information.  Please contact Emily Floyd at 619-557-5450 ext. 4566 or Martin Lane at 619-557-5450 ext. 4568 or email us Cabrillo National Monument invites amateur radio operators to broadcast from the park without a permit under the following conditions:* •Operating activity for day use only during regular park hours 9am – 5pm. •All radio and support equipment shall be contained to the operator’s vehicle. •Operators may use only one parking space. •Operators may not use the sidewalk for any support equipment. •The broadcast location is the northwest end of the parking lot facing San Diego bay (see map). •Antennas may only be raised to a height of no more than 20 feet. •Park entrance fees apply (a $10 entrance fee is valid for 7 days at Cabrillo National Monument). •No pets or smoking, please check our website for additional policies and regulations.  •Radio operators are responsible for their own equipment; any accidents are required to be reported to the Visitor Protection Rangers.  •If there are multiple individuals or groups broadcasting, the staff may limit the number of broadcasters or the time allowed broadcasting if the level of activity begins to affect or limit activities by other visitors. •On any one particular day of broadcasting, individuals or groups with a special use permit will have priority over individuals who do not. *These conditions and guidelines are subject to change and/ or cancellation at the discretion of the superintendent without notice. If you have any questions or need clarification about the above listed conditions please contact Emily Floyd at 619-557-5450 ext. 4566 or Martin Lane at 619-557-5450 ext. 4568 or email us Thank you for supporting the National Park Service and our mission to protect America’s unique and special places for future generations.
